vendor: Darena Solutions LLC dba Darena Health

access.description: The registered URL at www.darenasolutions.com redirects (301) to darena.health/meldrx-onc-hti1-certified, which is a Squarespace page containing a JavaScript redirect to /onc-hti1-certified. Three hops total to reach the actual content. The EHI section is anchored at #b10-EHI-Export-Documentation and is visible in-page without expanding accordions. A newsletter popup overlay appears after ~10 seconds and must be dismissed. The swagger documentation link referenced in the EHI section (app.meldrx.com/swagger/index.html) is dead (404). Replacement API docs exist at docs.darena.health but are not referenced from the EHI section.

product_context.description: Darena Health (formerly MeldRx, formerly BlueButtonPRO) is a FHIR middleware and compliance platform — NOT an EHR. It provides ONC-certified modules that EHR vendors integrate with to achieve certification. The platform handles FHIR API compliance (g10), EHI export (b10), clinical decision support (b11), and MIPS reporting. The 11 products listed in this certification are separate, independent EHR/practice management systems from 11 different developers that use Darena Health as their compliance layer. These products span radically different specialties: EZDERM (dermatology), PIMSY Platinum (behavioral health), eRAD RIS (radiology information), WITS (substance abuse treatment), Raintree (rehabilitation/therapy), Clinicmind (chiropractic/multi-specialty), Amrita (hospital information system), and others. Each of these products has its own patient portal, billing, scheduling, and specialty-specific functionality that stores data in its own database. Darena Health's FHIR layer only contains whatever data has been synchronized from those underlying systems — typically the USCDI-mapped clinical subset. This architecture means the EHI export almost certainly cannot access the full breadth of data stored by any of the 11 products.
product_context.broader_product_name: Multiple independent products (Amrita HIS, Clinicmind, Doctorsoft EHR, EZDERM, Epi-Management, Office Anywhere, PIMSY Platinum, Raintree, UnifiMD, WITS, eRAD RIS)

export_approach.description: Darena Health's EHI export uses FHIR Bulk Data Export (HL7 FHIR Bulk Data STU 1.0.1). The export is initiated via a Group-level $export operation on the FHIR server, producing NDJSON files of FHIR resources. Non-FHIR data is exported as DocumentReference resources (which can wrap C-CDA documents or other files). This is a pure FHIR-based export — there is no native database dump. The export can only contain data that has been loaded into the Darena Health FHIR workspace from the underlying EHR system. This is a significant limitation: the export is bounded by what the EHR-to-FHIR mapping covers, not by what the underlying EHR actually stores. For 11 different products across 11 specialties, the FHIR mapping is almost certainly limited to standard USCDI clinical data.

documentation_quality.description: The EHI export documentation is extraordinarily minimal — two sentences on a web page. There is no data dictionary, no schema documentation, no list of exported FHIR resource types, no field-level detail, no sample exports, and no documentation of what data categories are included. The referenced swagger documentation link is dead (404). Alternative API documentation exists at docs.darena.health (Postman format) which documents the Bulk Export API endpoints (System App Token, Get Workspace Details, Get Groups, Start Bulk Export, Get Content), but even these only document API mechanics — not what data is exported. The swagger JSON (OpenAPI 3.0.1) provides endpoint definitions but no FHIR resource schemas specific to the export. A developer receiving this export would need to understand FHIR R4 resource schemas independently — the documentation provides zero guidance on what resources to expect or what fields they contain.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: Coverage is almost certainly severely incomplete for all 11 products. Darena Health is a FHIR middleware layer — it can only export data that has been mapped and synchronized from each underlying EHR into the FHIR workspace. Standard FHIR R4 resources cover clinical data reasonably well (diagnoses, medications, labs, allergies, vitals) but have significant gaps in billing detail, secure messaging, insurance authorization specifics, scheduling, audit trails, and specialty-specific data. Given that the 11 products span dermatology, behavioral health, radiology, substance abuse treatment, rehabilitation, and hospital settings, each with deep specialty-specific data models, the FHIR layer is almost certainly capturing only a fraction of each product's stored EHI. The documentation provides no list of exported resource types, making it impossible to verify coverage. The DocumentReference mechanism for non-FHIR data (e.g., C-CDA documents) provides a theoretical path for additional data but only if the underlying EHR has implemented that mapping — which is not documented.

clinical.evidence: FHIR Bulk Data Export will include standard FHIR R4 clinical resources (Patient, Condition, MedicationRequest, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, Immunization, Procedure, DiagnosticReport, etc.) to the extent they have been mapped from the underlying EHR. The G9 section of the API docs shows CCDA creation capability. However, no specific list of exported resource types is provided in the documentation.

secure_messages.evidence: No mention of Communication, messaging, portal messages, or inbox in any documentation. FHIR R4's Communication resource could theoretically carry messages, but there is no evidence it is included. Multiple underlying products (Clinicmind, Raintree, PIMSY Platinum, etc.) likely have patient portals with messaging, but this data would need explicit mapping to Darena's FHIR layer.

billing_financial.evidence: No mention of Claim, ExplanationOfBenefit, ChargeItem, Invoice, or any billing/financial FHIR resources in the documentation. The underlying products (especially full EHRs like Clinicmind, Raintree, Doctorsoft) have extensive billing/RCM capabilities. FHIR R4 has limited billing resources compared to what EHR billing modules actually store. No evidence of billing data mapping.

insurance_coverage.evidence: No mention of Coverage, InsurancePlan, eligibility, or authorization resources. The underlying EHRs store detailed insurance information for claims processing, but there is no evidence this is mapped to Darena's FHIR layer.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No mention of Appointment, Schedule, or Slot resources. All underlying EHR products have scheduling functionality, but there is no evidence appointment data is included in the FHIR workspace.

documents_images.evidence: The documentation explicitly mentions DocumentReference resource types for non-FHIR resources including CCDA. The G10 section includes 'Upload DocumentReference' and the G9 section includes 'Get CCDA DocumentReference'. However, this is limited to documents that have been explicitly uploaded to the Darena workspace — it's unclear whether scanned documents, images, or specialty-specific media (e.g., dermatology photos from EZDERM, radiology images from eRAD RIS) are included.

audit_trails.evidence: No mention of AuditEvent, Provenance, or access logging in the export documentation. The certification includes 170.315(d)(2) 'Auditable Events and Tamper Resistance' and (d)(3) 'Audit Reports' but these appear to be about the Darena platform's own audit capabilities, not about exporting audit data from the underlying EHRs.

issues: The EHI export documentation consists of only two sentences — grossly insufficient for understanding what data is exported.
The swagger documentation link referenced in the b(10) section (app.meldrx.com/swagger/index.html) returns 404, leaving the primary reference dead.

Darena Health is a FHIR middleware platform, not an EHR — the export can only contain data that has been mapped and synchronized from 11 separate underlying EHR systems, which is almost certainly a small subset of each product's stored EHI.

11 different EHR products from 11 different developers across radically different specialties (dermatology, behavioral health, radiology, substance abuse, rehabilitation, hospital) all share this single 2-sentence EHI export documentation page.
No data dictionary, no list of exported FHIR resource types, no field-level documentation, and no sample exports are provided.

The FHIR Bulk Data Export approach inherently limits coverage to data that can be represented as standard FHIR R4 resources, which excludes most billing detail, insurance authorization specifics, scheduling data, secure messages, and specialty-specific data.

Specialty-specific data critical to the underlying products (e.g., dermatology images in EZDERM, behavioral health treatment plans in PIMSY, radiology reports in eRAD RIS, substance abuse treatment data in WITS) has no documented path to the FHIR export.
The registered URL requires three hops to reach content (301 redirect, JS redirect, then scroll to anchor) and the old domain (darenasolutions.com) is used in the CHPL registration.
No documentation of how non-FHIR data from underlying EHRs gets into the DocumentReference pathway — the mechanism exists in theory but its implementation for each of the 11 products is unknown.

downloaded_files.description: ONC Certification page containing the b(10) EHI Export Documentation section (two sentences describing FHIR Bulk Export and DocumentReference approach)

Postman-hosted API documentation covering Bulk Export endpoints (System App Token, Get Workspace Details, Get Groups, Start Bulk Export, Get Content) and FHIR API endpoints. Requires JavaScript to render.

OpenAPI 3.0.1 specification for Darena Health APIs. Contains endpoint definitions for FHIR operations, bulk export, CCDA import/export, MIPS reporting, and data models. Previously downloaded; the swagger UI is now 404 but this JSON was captured when it was live.

summary: Darena Health is a FHIR middleware/compliance platform (not an EHR) that provides ONC-certified modules to 11 separate EHR products from 11 different developers across diverse specialties. Its b(10) EHI export documentation consists of just two sentences describing FHIR Bulk Data Export and DocumentReference-based non-FHIR export, with the referenced swagger link now dead (404). The FHIR-only export approach inherently limits coverage to data that has been mapped from each underlying EHR to the FHIR workspace, almost certainly missing billing, insurance, scheduling, secure messages, audit trails, and specialty-specific data that the underlying EHR products store.
notes: This is a particularly problematic case for EHI completeness. The b(10) requirement covers 'all EHI stored by the product, of which the Health IT Module is a part.' The certified module (Darena Health) is a FHIR middleware layer that sits alongside — not inside — the actual EHR products. The products (Raintree, Clinicmind, EZDERM, etc.) are the systems that actually store patient data. Darena Health only sees what the EHR has pushed to it via FHIR/CCDA mappings. This creates a fundamental architectural gap: the certified module's export capability is limited to data that exists in the middleware layer, while the bulk of EHI remains in the underlying EHR databases that Darena Health has no direct access to. Each of the 11 products would need its own comprehensive data mapping to close this gap, and there is no documentation suggesting this has been done comprehensively for any of them.
